item.title: insurgents kill at least 35 in attack on an afghan road crew
item.description: insurgents ambushed an afghan construction crew working on a road project in southeastern afghanistan early thursday morning, killing at least 35.

item.title: japanese town holds on to hope
item.description: in a town where more than one in 10 is dead or missing, people seem to exist in suspended animation.

item.title: supreme court rejects illegal immigrants' tuition case
item.description: the supreme court on monday rejected a challenge to a california law that gives illegal immigrants the same in-state college tuition rates as legal state residents, another contentious issue in the nation's immigration policy debate.

item.title: joy, then wariness, in post-bin laden america
item.description: the heady u.s. street celebrations that erupted after the death of osama bin laden gave way on monday to stepped up security amid fears of revenge from the worldwide militant networks he inspired.

item.description: in an unusual, and apparently heated, closed-door session, pakistan's spy chief denied that pakistan maintained any links with militant groups, according to lawmakers.

item.description: for an ailment with no known cause and subjective symptoms, definitions differ, and so do diagnoses.

item.title: barry weiss replaces l.a. reid at record label

item.description: the withdrawal of security forces from some provinces has left a power vacuum that al-qaeda is trying to fill.

item.description: anti-riot police officers clashed with student protesters at uganda's most prestigious university friday as students demonstrated against tuition increases and widespread government corruption.

item.description: simon cowell wants his former "american idol" sparring partner paula abdul and british singer cheryl cole join him on the u.s. version of his tv contest "the x factor."

item.description: after 9/11, president george w. bush famously urged americans to shop to bolster a shocked u.s. economy. now after osama bin laden's killing, consumers are snapping up memorabilia of his dramatic killing.

item.title: defense demands damages as demjanjuk trial concludes

item.title: egypt detains ex-energy minister for questioning
item.description: egypt's public prosecutor on thursday ordered former energy minister sameh fahmy and five other senior energy officials detained for questioning into a natural gas deal with israel the government is reviewing.

item.title: saleh calls for early election as yemenis protest

item.title: saleh refuses to sign yemen deal despite pressure
item.description: yemeni president ali abdullah saleh refused to sign a deal to step down on sunday, the third time such an agreement has fallen through at the last minute, despite pressure from gulf arab and western mediators.

item.title: yemen opposition signs transition of power deal
item.description: yemen's opposition signed a gulf-brokered transition deal on saturday that will ease president ali abdullah saleh out of power within a month, provided he ratifies the agreement as promised on sunday.

item.title: heavy clashes erupt in yemen capital, 21 dead
item.description: yemeni loyalist forces fought street battles with guards from a powerful tribal federation whose leader has sided with protesters demanding an end to president ali abdullah saleh's rule, witnesses said on tuesday.

item.description: the head of nato said on wednesday the u.s. operation in which al qaeda leader osama bin laden was killed on monday was justified.

item.description: yemeni loyalist forces fought a gunbattle on monday with opponents of entrenched president ali abdullah saleh one day after he backed out of an accord for him to step down.

item.title: civil war looms as big blasts rock yemeni capital
item.description: heavy explosions rocked the yemeni capital sanaa in the small hours of thursday as fighting to topple the veteran president, ali abdullah saleh, threatened to descend into civil war.

item.title: civil war looms in yemen, saleh urged to quit
item.description: yemen teetered on the verge of civil war on friday as president ali abdullah saleh defied calls from opponents and world leaders for him to relinquish power.

item.description: yemeni forces loyal to president ali abdullah saleh opened fire on protesters in the southern city of taiz on sunday, killing at least six people and wounding 120, hospital sources said.

item.title: yemen truce ends in blasts, stokes civil war worries
item.description: street fighting raged in yemen's capital on tuesday ending a tenuous ceasefire between tribal groups and forces loyal to president ali abdullah saleh and edging the impoverished arab state closer to civil war.
